Publication.title: Integration of Text and Audio Features for Genre Classification in Music Information Retrieval
Publication.abstractText: Multimedia content can be described in versatile ways as its essence is not limited to one view. For music data these multiple views could be a song's audio features as well as its lyrics. Both of these modalities have their advantages as text may be easier to search in and could cover more of the 'content semantics' of a song, while omitting other types of semantic categorisation. (Psycho)acoustic feature sets, on the other hand, provide the means to identify tracks that 'sound simi-lar' while less supporting other kinds of semantic categorisation. Those discerning characteristics of different feature sets meet users' differing information needs. We will explain the nature of text and audio feature sets which describe the same audio tracks. Moreover, we will propose the use of textual data on top of low level audio features for music genre classification. Further, we will show the impact of different combinations of audio features and textual features based on content words.
